### Prerequisites

We recommend that readers study the sections **Scientific Method**, **Sources**, **First steps**, **Understanding text** in order to deepen the knowledge summarized in this material

Introduction

Investigating a historical fact — such as genealogy — requires following the steps of the scientific method (scientific method). This includes the ability to reproduce results and the possibility of refutation. When researching a person, findings must be based on primary sources that can be confirmed or challenged by other researchers.

As we begin to explore our family tree, many questions arise, such as: What are the names of my ancestors? How should I build a family tree? Who is my earliest known ancestor? Which software should I use to create the tree? Can I trust every blog that talks about genealogy?

On this page, we suggest a pathway that will help you discover your ancestors while also gaining an understanding of the scientific research process.

Talk to the family

The first step is to talk with older relatives, who often had contact with previous generations of the family. During these conversations, request access to documents related to your ancestors and listen to old family stories. However, always try to confirm such accounts with written records.

### Documentation

After collecting documents from your ancestors, the next step is to look for records of later generations in the institutions responsible for preserving them. Since older documents did not follow modern standards, it is important to be prepared for challenges — which should be seen as opportunities for learning.

#### Primary sources

In Brazil, I followed this path to gather information about my ancestors:

• Requesting birth, marriage, and death records of direct ancestors and, when necessary, of their siblings.
  • Researching in forums, public archives, and museums for documents such as population registers, inventories, and wills mentioning our ancestors.
  • Looking for references to our ancestors in newspapers of the time (such as the collections of the Memória, Biblioteca Nacional).
  • For the 19th century, considering the union of State and Church. It is essential to examine religious records — baptisms, marriages, deaths, and wills — in the churches where ancestors lived. If such records are not found locally, they may be stored in dioceses. The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints provides access to many old religious records through its Family Search project.
  • For the 17th and 16th centuries, consulting Inventories and Testaments in São Paulo, as well as the Wills (Volume I and Volume II) and São Paulo Town Hall.
  • For earlier periods, turning to indexes and then to the Indexes and subsequently explore the Royal Chancellary. Other resources available at the 'Torre do Tombo,' including the General Inquiries and documents once under the purview of ecclesiastical bodies like the Cabido da Sé de Coimbra, and inquisitorial records like those of the Lisboa Inquisition.
  • Regional chronicles can also provide valuable clues about the context and people of specific historical periods.

#### Secondary Sources

Secondary sources must always be checked in order to confirm whether the people mentioned are indeed connected to the family line being studied.

In this project, the following works were consulted:

• Scientific publications, such as the journals of the Instituto Histórico Geográfico de São Paulo and the Instituto Histórico e Geográfico do Espírito Santo, Revista Genea, and the ASBRAP. In many cases, they cite the primary sources used. However, each article must be critically evaluated. For example, in ASBRAP itself, genealogist Marta Maria Amato updated, in issue 6, data on Francisca de Macedo that had previously been published in issue 4 by Cid Guimarães.
  • Although it is not a scientific journal, the Projeto Compartilhar should be recognized as a scientific endeavor since it follows the scientific method in its analyses.
  • Among genealogical works, the following stand out: Nuno Borrego, Manuel Abranches de Soveral, Christian Settipani, José Mattoso, José Augusto de Sottomayor-Pizarro, and Augusto Ferreira do Amaral. While there are other high-quality publications, I only mention those I have studied in depth.

Software

There are several programs and websites that can help with creating a family tree. However, many do not verify whether the connections and data entered are consistent. Therefore, it is advisable to use these tools with caution and always keep an independent version of your tree when using collaborative platforms.

### Sharing your findings

Discovering our ancestors is always a source of pride. Many researchers develop projects to share these discoveries. Below, we present some examples that may inspire you to share your own family history:

Blogs and websites

When it comes to blogs, the same caution applied to articles and books should be used. Many authors, driven by personal interests, may selectively choose information instead of presenting documentary evidence in its entirety. Given this scenario, we suggest some examples of blogs and websites by researchers and project collaborators, which share family stories along with their sources, allowing readers to verify the information:

  • Blog (Yepé).
  • Site about (Lemes' family).
  • Blog about distinct families (Genealogia e Origens).
  • Site about the history of (Leopoldina)
  • Blog about the old (city of Queluz).
  • Blog about families living in (Brazilian South).
  • Blog about the South region of (Espirito Santo).
  • Blog with documentation to help our research (Genealogia FB).
  • Site with content to help research in "Zona da Mata Mineira" (Fato GEN).
  • João Vaz Carvalho's genealogy and other families that are near geographically (Genealogia de João Vaz Carvalho ...).
  • Genetic studies developed by Brazilian-Founders in (Family Tree DNA)
  • Marcelo José Machado Coelho genealogical blog (MACCOE GENEALOGIA).
  • Site about the history of Montes Claros (História de Montes Claros).
  • Genealogy of Eduardo Olifer, the author of the website dedicated to the history of Montes Claros. (Nepotibus).
  • Blog about the history of Queluz de Minas (O Faiscador de Queluz de Minas).

### Genealogical Illusions

When consulting books such as nobiliaries, it is not uncommon to find fabricated connections. These distortions are usually discovered when we compare documents contemporary to the people who lived with nobiliaries written centuries later. This scenario leads us to a reflection:
Reflection 1: About genealogical trees

Some genealogical errors often arise because respected genealogists find evidence that seems to support an initial line of reasoning. However, with new discoveries, it becomes clear that this reasoning was flawed.

text.text: **Slide 1** presents 16 kings (*ajawob*) of Copán who, at first glance, might be interpreted as 16 consecutive generations. However, a more in-depth study of the period in which they lived and the city’s constructions shows that not all the kings are known, and that some of the figures represented on the altar may even have been brothers (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

Reflection 2: Us and Them

If confusion exists even regarding well-documented figures such as kings, is it not even more likely that errors occur in the records of overall people?

### Conclusion

In this text, we reflected on some of the steps necessary to build our own family tree. We also saw that appearances can be deceiving — which is why we must consult all known primary sources to better understand our ancestors.
